comments.commentBody: I'm pretty sure both presidential candidates, and certainly the sitting president, have spoken freely and frequently about the need for America to step up it's propaganda campaign against ISIL particularly via the internet. I'm not sure what is wrong with "counter programming" to anti-American jihadist "news".  And, actually, calling the programming "Voice of America" is pretty above board.  As for it being in Somalia which I assume you are mentioning as though we are trampling on the Somalian government's rights to control what Somalians hear -- we do live in a global world and most people don't actually like the idea of a nation trying to control what it's citizens hear like China does.  So are the listeners in Somalia or are they citizens of the world and entitled to hear from the world at large?  As for Radio Free Europe I hate to break it to you but that is not news.  I don't know about this prohibition of distribution of government content to Americans, etc. but, guess what, everyone was in the military during the wars and mostly oversees and exposed to Radio Free Europe even if we weren't listening to it domestically.  It wasn't a secret.  Nor a secret that it was American/allied made news.  When countries could control the airwaves and only allowed state media Radio Free Europe was a very welcome and appreciated additional voice and resource and cherished by tens of millions around the world. You can find much worse governments than America, imperfect as it is.

Lee Bo, a British citizen, disappeared in HK only to show up in China; and have since returned to HK to give up his British citizenship.  Most believed it is  probably out of duress and legally not binding.  Same with the chairperson of the Parliament who has much closer ties and history with Britain.  All Hong Kongers are victims.  But God gave man free will and made us in His image and likeness, that is our saving grace.  We see that in the bookseller who speaks out in hiding; and in the young Legislators who run on empty to speak out for their constituents, and by extension, the good of the world.  Pray for the Communists who most in need of God's mercy.

If PRC tried to stop booksellers from publishing books of political entertainment for the citizens of their own country by kidnapping them from HK, it is not stopping itself or its many fractions to buy up newspapers in HK and publish dailies of Cultural Revolution style reporting on political intrigues, innuendos and Marxist style purges and infighting in the CCP oligarchy for the entertainment of HK readers.  But they are seen as just that, entertainment, Soviet style.  Nobody in their right mind in HK or anywhere else, barred one, would think of kidnapping them.  HK is not China.  That is what it means.  If it were, HK people would be going around the world kidnapping the equivalents of the publishers of Vanity Fair, George magazine, National Enquirer, News of the World ... to achieve the Brave New World.  And that is only politically.  That is why the city of All Nations were on the street for 79 days 2 years ago and in the Parliament now.  If that voice is silenced,  it would be injustice.  The rest of the world would have to carry on their own and make the sacrifices these people make with their conscience.

Hong Kong's autonomy has always been under threat.

As long as it makes economic sense for China to maintain HK as it is, they will do so. When China decides it no longer makes sense to maintain HK, they'll shut the place down just as quickly as an unlicensed noodle vendor.

Eventually they'll have the Spratly's built up to where they want it. Then they'll start to swing the gate shut. Probably around the same time they inform Taiwan their day is done.

I also suspect China thinks of the Spratly's as a futuristic Guangzhou for a Canton System. Control the trade from the south.
Taiwan will gate the north.

Does anyone here really want to get into a shooting war with China?

There is no question that the harsh reprisals had a chiing effect on book publishers. But hey, business is business. The print media, whether pro or against the mainland government, are experiencing declining readership. Which explains why so many print publishers are going out of business, and online bloggers are still thriving - the law of supply and demand.
Be like Bo and Nike, just "do it".

Hardly anyone i know drinks Coke and other sugary water concoctions.

The industry is on its way down, facing the fate of the Big Tobacco. And the time could not come too soon.

I think it was FDR who said 'we must stand up to the mob and tax the poor again".

And LBJ who said 'why educate when we can tax, then we can pay ourselves more'.

California, the highest gov't pay in the country, the highest difference between public and private sector pay.
Pales in comparison to Coca-Cola & Pepsi. Next?

But there's nothing surprising here. Conservatives generally find people terrifying and want the most space possible between them and others, plus the ability to defend against people who do breach the perimeter, even if that means shooting them dead. Liberals are in general far more interested in other people, including -- maybe particularly -- others unlike themselves, and trust others far enough to believe that a tumult of interaction and exchange is a good and healthy thing.

This is a fair and accurate account of where Swansea city is at the moment. However Bradley has been thrown into a toxic situation where it may be impossible for him to succeed. Poor recruitment for 18 months has resulted in squad that cannot compete with clubs of similar revenues.
I think it's unfair to say that Bradley isn't taken seriously because of his accent, this club is welcoming of players and coaches from all nations, in fact you have to respect the American attitudes and approach to all sport. Narrow mindedness will only hold Swansea back ,an open approach is what has allowed us to succeed in the past.

English, Welsh, and Scottish soccer is in aggregate an underperforming disgrace for 50 years. Get over yourselves, Swansea fans and parochial EPL snobs. Managers don't play, or win or lose. Players do those things. So get a grip and get enough top flight quality players to be credible and taken seriously in your  criticism of Bradley. He may be the best manager or the worst. Who knows yet?  You surely do not.

The new American owners must be following the Randy Lerner playbook.

So far they have achieved about as much, or as little, as RL did. Of course RL managed to screw up the Cleveland Browns....though the new owner has managed to make things worse. The Browns are 0-9 so far this season and the owner is on his4th or 5th coach. But who's counting?
I never was impressed with Bradley when he was the USA coach.

What's pathetic about BPL "fans" is their inability to realize it's the men on the field who lose matches.  Through the din of "fan" complaints regarding ownership, board members, managers, I have heard nothing of the complete lack of ability on the pitch. This mentality does not exist in the United States.  We believe professional athletes are hired to perform.  I've watched each Swans match since Guidolin's last, and the team is terrible.  They cannot finish, they lack pace, and, most importantly, they lack heart.  A coach cannot fix these problems.  Bob Bradley's U.S. team outperformed England in the 2010 World Cup because his U.S. team had heart.  The reaction from Swans fans has been pathetic.

The team is terrible.  It's the "professionals" on the field.  They were terrible last season, they were terrible this season under Guidolin, and they're terrible now.  The players lack skill.  Any player with serious skill would not want to play for Swansea.  Anyone who has actually played the game knows the coach controls very little once the whistle blows.  If a team lacks talent, a coach cannot overcome that complete lack of talent....oh wait, Swansea actually has one of the few coaches who could accomplish this seemingly impossible task.  If I recall correctly, the US topped the group ahead of England under Bradley in South Africa with a mediocre U.S. team (granted, that team had a level of heart a British team could only dream of).  He almost took an Egypt team in the throws of a revolution to the 2014 World Cup.  Swansea is not deserving of such a man.

Four matches your limit, Rob? Bradley can't go on the field and play defense for a team that can't do so of its own volition.
In Ki and Cork, there are guys who in the past have shown the ability to play central midfield at Premier League quality. But that back four is close to irredeemable. If the owners don't try to find a couple of backliners, and a striker in January, they're going down.
Bradley is a convenient scapegoat, but if it makes you feel better to blame him, go on. But think about the pkayers your team management sold off long before Bradley got the call. Sure could use Michu and Ashley Williams, eh?

That's ridiculous. Everton got blasted by Chelsea 5-0 just the day before. Manchester United has the highest paid squad in the Premier League. Bradley/Swansea was not going to win that game by pressing forward. They would have lost by a more lopsided margin.

This managerial choice was doomed from the start. Bradley has no experience in English football at any level. The tactics against Manchester United showed he is out of his depth; playing a slow press and camping in their own half. It was the most abysmal performance by a Premier League team for several years

Swansea's rise from the depths of the English leagues is a great story. It is sad to see it now going in reverse. The fans deserve better

Must be a baseball fan cuz you don't know **** about soccer.
Honors
Chicago Fire
MLS Cup: 1998
U.S. Open Cup: 1998, 2000
United States
CONCACAF Gold Cup:
Winner: 2007
Runners-up: 2009, 2011
FIFA Confederations Cup:
Runners-up: 2009
Loser  ... Gone by Xmas ....

"that Clinton's actions show no criminality" is not what the letter said. It reaffirmed the first letter, which concluded much more than that.

It specified that if anyone else had done the same thing they would be prosecuted.

Since then, the Hillary Defense has been tried, and failed, and the FBI prosecuted others for the same things done by Hillary.

Not enough to indict a Presidential candidate in the middle of a race is not the same as "no criminality" because of the public policy concern about interference in an election.

Even then, the policy is not against ALL interference, it just set a higher bar. The FBI concern was that she'd gone over even that higher bar.
Most fruit juices are just as loaded with sugar as soda pop is.

"Most Expensive Thing on California’s Ballot"

don't forget the proposed tobacco tax increase of $2. taxes on beer, wine and liquor would be a good comparison to the proposed soda pop tax, and a good reminder of the damages that alcohol causes to our bodies and to society. fortunately, sweetened carbonated beverages generally do not cause drunken driving, other accidents, cirrhosis and other diseases, even though many dentists might say that they provide a steady source of patients.

i vote with my pocketbook: "Many Americans now say they are trying to avoid the products, and national sales of such drinks have been slipping."
...

why not propose a subsidy on fruit juices, paid for by the tax revenue on soda pop? california farmers and voters might like that, although dentists and nutritionists would probably offer various opinions.
Thank you.

Exactly the opposite. We do it for no reward. Trust me when I say this article and pictures were handpicked to show only a very small part of our race. Most of us do not want the publicity nor the the type of people this article may bring. We are a small group of people that love what we do for numerous reasons. We gather together and celebrate each others accomplishments like you would at a family picnic or reunion of best friends (the kind of family you love at least).
I doubt everything you do or eat is good for your body. I might be wrong, maybe you are perfect.

I wonder how little one must have in their "soul" to not only have such negative thoughts but to take the time to write them. Please come volunteer at one of these "events" and you would have your mind changed. The funny part is how you skew your own comment to "O look at me," I ran under a 3hr. marathon. There is a high probability that you have done a lot more damage to your body training and racing "20" marathons than I have. Your recovery stats may be true for you but it is not the same for everyone.

While the article is notably well-written, it failed to describe the event in its entirety. This race is indeed extreme, but it's certainly not absurd. The participants would not be doing these races if they didn't love the drive and push that it takes. Some pain is nothing compared to the feeling of completing an unimaginable goal. What's really absurd is the fact that you think you understand the wonderful people that are apart of these events.
